nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: On the Way to the Park
nodes.text: You’re walking to the park with your child. Today, your new partner will join you for the first time. Your child knows ‘a friend’ might come, but not much more.

choices.label: Name what’s happening in a simple, honest way.
choices.text: You say: “Hey, my friend Alex is joining us today. We’ve been spending some time together and I’d like you to meet.”

choices.label: Keep it vague and avoid defining the relationship.
choices.text: You say: “A friend might show up later,” and quickly change the subject.

choices.label: Overload the child with details about the relationship.
choices.text: You launch into a long explanation about how you met, why it matters, and how nothing will change at home.

nodes.speaker: New Partner
nodes.title: First Hello
nodes.text: At the park, your new partner waves and walks over. Your child hides slightly behind you, peeking out with curiosity and caution.

choices.label: Model a warm but low-pressure introduction.
choices.text: You say: “Alex, this is Maya. Maya, this is Alex. You don’t have to talk yet if you don’t feel like it.”

choices.label: Prompt the child to be extra friendly.
choices.text: You nudge: “Come on, say hi properly, don’t be rude.”

choices.label: Let your partner take the lead completely.
choices.text: You stay quiet as Alex kneels down and starts talking directly to the child without checking in with you first.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Shared Activity
nodes.text: The three of you end up near the swings. The child watches, still gauging if this new person is ‘safe’ in their world.

choices.label: Invite a simple joint activity the child can opt into.
choices.text: You ask: “Do you want us to push you on the swing together, or should I push and Alex watch?”

choices.label: Step aside and let your partner bond quickly and intensely.
choices.text: You suggest Alex take over the swing completely while you scroll your phone nearby.

choices.label: Keep your partner at a distance to ‘protect’ the child.
choices.text: You keep chatting only with your child, barely including Alex in the interaction.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of the Outing
nodes.text: On the way home, your child is quieter than usual. They’re processing. The introduction may have been small on the outside, but it was big on the inside.

choices.label: Invite a light, open check-in with the child.
choices.text: You ask: “How was it for you meeting Alex today? Anything you liked or didn’t like?”

choices.label: Avoid the topic to ‘keep things calm’.
choices.text: You talk about homework and dinner instead, filing the whole day under “don’t stir the waters.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Quick Reflection
nodes.text: Every introduction carries a message: not just who this new person is, but whether the child’s pace and feelings are allowed to matter.

choices.label: Notice what you did to protect the child’s pace.
choices.text: You recognize the moments where you gave the child choice, information, or space.

choices.label: Notice what you’d handle differently next time.
choices.text: You mentally circle one thing you’d tweak for the next introduction or hangout.
